Name: Circuit Analysis I
Description: The fundamentals of analysis of lumped linear time-invariant circuits; network theorems; operational amplifiers; first order circuits; DC analysis of diodes, BJT, and FET circuits.
Prerequisites: MATH 101 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153, PHYS 158

Name: Circuit Analysis II
Description: Phasor analysis and AC three phase systems power; transfer functions; Bode plots; filters and resonance; Laplace transforms; transformers and mutual inductance; two-port networks. First and second order circuits.
Prerequisites: All of PHYS 153, MATH 101 and one of EECE 251, EECE 263, ELEC 201, ELEC 203 and one of MATH 255, MATH 256

Name: Basic Circuit Analysis
Description: Ideal passive elements and sources; Kirchhoff's Laws; DC circuits; natural and complete response of first order circuits; operational amplifiers; impedance; phasors; complex power. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

Name: Linear Circuits
Description: Basic concepts and analysis techniques in the context of electric and electronic circuits including Bode plots and the Laplace transform. Treatment of RLC circuits, phasors, op-amps. Introduction to nonlinear circuit elements, diodes, BJT, FET circuits.
Prerequisites: MATH 152 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 158, PHYS 153

Name: Electronics Laboratory
Description: Experiments involving electronic devices and circuits.

Name: Engineering Electromagnetics
Description: Electrostatics, electric currents, dielectrics, capacitance, electrostatic potential, magnetostatics.
Credits: 2 (includes MATH264 in STT, which is 1 additional credit)
Prerequisites: One of MATH 263, MATH 253 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153, PHYS 158

Name: Signals and Systems
Description: Complex numbers, LTI systems, convolution sum, discrete-time Fourier series and transforms, z-transform, sampling, introduction to filtering and modulation, feedback systems, stability.

Name: Selected Topics in Biomedical Engineering
Description: Effective communication in a multi-disciplinary environment, introduction to emerging areas of biomedical engineering and biotechnology, ethics, and responsibility. Restricted to students admitted to the Biomedical Engineering program in Electrical Engineering.

Name: Technical Communication
Description: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, BMEG 201 or APSC 201.
Prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150

Name: Electrical Engineering Design Studio I
Description: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, and microcomputers.
Prerequisites: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211

Name: Biomedical Engineering Design Studio
Description: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, microcomputers with applications in biomedical engineering. Final group project requiring oral presentation of student-prepared slides.
Corequisites: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of EECE 269, ELEC 221

Name: Introduction to Microcomputers
Description: Boolean algebra; combinational and sequential circuits; organization and operation of microcomputers, memory addressing modes, representation of information, instruction sets, machine and assembly language programming, systems programs, I/O structures, I/O interfacing and I/O programming, introduction to digital system design using microcomputers. Credit will be granted for only one of CPEN 211, CPEN 312, EECE 256, EECE 259 or EECE 355.

Name: Principles of Software Construction
Description: Design, implementation, reasoning about software systems: abstraction and specification of software, testing, verification, abstract data types, object-oriented design, type hierarchies, concurrent software design.

Name: Software Design for Engineers
Description: Introduction to robust software design: static typing, procedural specifications, unit testing, black-box and white-box tests, user- defined data types (representations, invariants, abstraction functions), data abstractions, communicating design (e.g., UML).

Name: Technical Communication
Description: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, BMEG 201 or APSC 201.
Prerequisites: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150

Name: Computer Engeering Design Studio I
Description: Design projects involving hardware (electronic devices and circuits, microcomputers) and software.
